Relation.Pattern: . alstonia scholaris (l.) r. br., locally known as dita, is used for the treatment of fever, chronic diarrhea, dysentery, beri-beri, congestion of the liver, and ulcers.

. chemical investigation of the dichloromethane extract of the leaves of alstonia scholaris (l.) r. br has yielded mixtures of erythrodiol , uvaol , and betulin in a 1:1:1 ratio, oleanolic acid and ursolic acid in a 2:1 ratio, beta-amyrin acetate and alpha-amyrin acetate in a 1:4 ratio, and beta-sitosterol and stigmasterol in a 3:2 ratio; squalene , beta-sitosteryl-3beta-glucopyranoside-6'-o-fatty acid esters , and chlorophyll a.
194 acetate; and alpha-amyrin fatty acid esters, beta-amyrin fatty acid esters, lupeol fatty acid esters and phytyl fatty acid esters from the flowers of alstonia scholaris.
195 general isolation procedure a glass column 12 inches in height and 0 squalene, inch internal diameter was used for the chromatography.

all fractions were monitored by thin layer chromatography.
all solvents used are analytical grade.

column chromatography was performed with silica gel 60 (70-230 mesh, merck).

final purifications were conducted using pasteur pipettes as columns.
five milliliter fractions were collected.

fractions from this column were combined and rechromatographed using ch3cn:et2o:ch2cl2 (1.5:1.5:7, v/v) to afford beta-sitosteryl-3beta-glucopyranoside-6'-o-fatty acid esters, (3 mg) after trituration with petroleum ether..
fractions with spots of the same rf values were combined and rechromatographed in appropriate solvent systems until tlc pure isolates were obtained.
hz, h-22) and squalene, 00 (dd, j = 8.8, 15.
hz, h-23) suggested that the ratio of beta-sitosterol, and stigmasterol, is about 3:2..

in this study, the leaves of alstonia scholaris afforded mixtures of erythrodiol , uvaol , and betulin ; oleanolic acid and ursolic ; beta-amyrin acetate and alpha-amyrin acetate ; beta-sitosterol and stigmasterol ; squalene ; beta-sitosteryl-3beta-glucopyranoside-6' -o-fatty acid esters ; and chlorophyll a.

isolation of the chemical constituents from the leaves of alstonia scholaris the air-dried alstonia scholaris leaves (113.21 g) were ground in a blender, soaked in ch2cl2 for 3 days and then filtered.

keywords: alstonia scholaris, apocynaceae, erythrodiol, uvaol, erythrodiol, betulin, oleanolic acid, ursolic acid, betaamyrin acetate, alpha-amyrin acetate, beta-sitosterol, stigmasterol, squalene, beta-sitosteryl-3beta-glucopyranoside-6'-o-fatty acid esters, chlorophyll a

many studies reported the isolation of alkaloids from alstonia scholaris [15-24]. in an earlier study, we reported the isolation of cycloeucalenol, cycloartanol, lupeol, lupeol acetate, and betulin from the leaves of alstonia scholaris.
one milliliter fractions were collected.

previous studies reported the isolation of 2,3-secofernane triterpenoids, alstonic acids a and b ; 3beta-acetate-24-nor-urs-4,12-diene ester triterpene, 3beta-hydroxy-24-nor-urs4,12,28-triene triterpene, 3,28-beta-diacetoxy-5-olea-triterpene, alpha-amyrin acetate, and ursolic acid lupeol acetate ; flavonoids ; monoterpene , triterpene [8-10]; iridoids ; megastigmane-3beta,4alpha,9-triol, 7-megastigmene6, 9-triol and c13-norisoprenoid from alstonia scholaris.

sample collection samples of alstonia scholaris (l.) r. br leaves were collected from the de la salle university - manila campus in october 2015.

silica gel chromatography of the dichloromethane extract of the leaves of alstonia scholaris yielded squalene, beta-sitosteryl-3beta-glucopyranoside-6'-o-fatty acid esters, chlorophyll a, . the nmr spectra of erythrodiol, are in accordance with data reported in the literature for erythrodiol ; uvaol, for uvaol ; betulin, for betulin ; oleanolic acid, for oleanolic acid ; 2a):ursolic acid, for ursolic acid ; 3a for beta-amyrin acetate ; 3a):alpha-amyrin acetate, for alpha-amyrin acetate ; beta-sitosterol, for beta-sitosterol ; stigmasterol, for stigmasterol ; squalene, for squalene ; beta-sitosteryl-3beta-glucopyranoside-6'-o-fatty acid esters, for beta-sitosteryl-3betaglucopyranoside-6'-o-fatty acid esters ; and chlorophyll a, for chlorophyll a
the 10% acetone in ch2cl2 fraction was rechromatographed (2 ) using petroleum ether to yield squalene, (4 mg).

the 1:1:1 ratio of the mixture of :: was deduced from the integrations and intensities of the 1h nmr resonances for the olefinic protons of erythrodiol, at squalene, 17 (t, j = 3. hz, h-12) , uvaol, at squalene, 12 (t, j = 3. hz, h-12) , and betulin, at 4.66 (br d, j = 2 hz, ha-29) and 4.56 (br s, hb-29).

the 1:4 ratio of the mixture of beta-amyrin acetate (3a):alpha-amyrin acetate was deduced from the integrations and intensities of the 1h nmr resonances for the olefinic protons of 3a at squalene, 15 (t, j = 3. hz, h-3) and 3a):alpha-amyrin acetate, at squalene, 10 (t, j = 3. hz, h3).
the 20% acetone in ch2cl2 fraction was rechromatographed (2 ) using petroleum ether to afford a mixture of 3a and 3a):alpha-amyrin acetate, (4 mg) after washing with petroleum ether.

the 2:1 ratio of the mixture of oleanolic acid (2a):ursolic acid was deduced from the integrations and intensities of the 1h nmr resonances for the olefinic protons of oleanolic acid, at squalene, 27 (t, j = 3. hz, h-3) and 2a):ursolic acid, at squalene, 24 (t, j = 3. hz, h-3).
the 30% acetone in ch2cl2 fraction was rechromatographed (3 ) using 10% etoac in petroleum ether to yield chlorophyll a, (3 mg) after washing with petroleum ether, followed by et2o.
the 40% acetone in ch2cl2 fraction was rechromatographed using 15% etoac in petroleum ether, followed by 20% etoac in petroleum ether.
the 50% acetone in ch2cl2 fraction was rechromatographed (3 ) using 20% etoac in petroleum ether to yield a mixture of oleanolic acid, and 2a):ursolic acid, (3 mg) after washing with petroleum ether.
the 60% acetone in ch2cl2 fraction was rechromatographed using ch3cn:et2o:ch2cl2 (1:1:8, v/v).
the crude extracts were fractionated by silica gel chromatography using increasing proportions of acetone in ch2cl2 at 10% increment by volume as eluents.

the essential oil of the flowers of alstonia scholaris yielded 2-dodecyloxirane (31.83%), 1,2-dimethoxy-4-(2-propenyl)benzene (8.49%), spinacene beta-sitosteryl-3beta-glucopyranoside-6'-o-fatty acid esters, 09%), 1,54dibromotetrapentacontane squalene, 13%), 2 beta-sitosteryl-3beta-glucopyranoside-6'-o-fatty acid esters, 10,15-tetramethylheptadecane (4.91%), terpinyl acetate (3.74%), linalool (2.22%), tritetracontane (2.17%), 2-(3-methyl-1,3-butadienyl)-1,3,3-trimethyl-1-cyclohexanol (1.78%), 9-methyl-5methylene-8-decen-2-one (1.58%) as the main constituents.

the ethanolic extract of the flowers of alstonia scholaris afforded alstoprenyol, 3-beta-hydroxy-28-beta-acetoxy-5-olea, alstoprenylene 3beta-acetate-24-nor-urs-4,12,2'-triene ester, alpha-amyrin acetate, alpha-amyrin, lupeol acetate, and 3beta-hydroxy-24-nor-urs-4,12,28-triene.

the fractions eluted with 15% etoac in petroleum ether were combined and rechromatographed using the same solvent to afford a mixture of beta-sitosterol, and stigmasterol, (3 mg) after washing with petroleum ether.

the fractions eluted with 20% etoac in petroleum ether were combined and rechromatographed using the same solvent to yield a mixture of erythrodiol, uvaol, and betulin, squalene, mg) after washing with petroleum ether.

the integrations of the 1h nmr resonances for the olefinic protons of beta-sitosterol, at squalene, 33 (brd, j = squalene, hz, h-6) and stigmasterol, at squalene, 33 (brd, j = squalene, hz, h-6), squalene, 13 (dd, j = 8.4, 15.
the presence of the acetate functional groups was deduced from the appearance of methyl singlets at 2.02 and 2.
the samples were authenticated at the botany division, philippine national museum.
the solvent was evaporated under vacuum to afford a crude extract (1.22 g) which was chromatographed using increasing proportions of acetone in ch2cl2 in 10% increments by volume.
the structures of squalene, beta-sitosteryl-3beta-glucopyranoside-6'-o-fatty acid esters, chlorophyll a, are presented in fig..
the structures of squalene, beta-sitosteryl-3beta-glucopyranoside-6'-o-fatty acid esters, chlorophyll a, were identified by comparison of their nmr data with literature data.
thin layer chromatography was performed with plastic backed plates coated with silica gel f254 (merck) and the plates were visualized by spraying with vanillin/h2so4 solution followed by warming.
